articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
I grew up in central Maryland, and lived in Iowa and Wisconsin before moving to Minnesota.
Things I enjoy include:
Keeping up with my three kids.
Going to the dog park with my golden retriever, Beary.
Reading. Right now I’m on a Sci-Fi and Fantasy kick. I really enjoy Brandon Sanderson’s work, but I’m not sure I can pin down a favorite author.
Woodworking (though I rarely actually do this!)
Telling myself I’ll start playing my trumpet again after more than a decade away (Maybe this will be the year I actually do it!)

            Bio
            I’m an Assistant Professor of Statistics in the Department of
            Mathematics and Statistics at Carleton College. I
            teach statistics at all levels of the curriculum and am
            passionate about communicating the beauty and power of
            modern statistical methods to my students. My research
            focuses on incorporating realistic computation and
            visualization into the classroom, exploring the potential of
            visual inference, developing better visualizations to
            explore complex models, and developing useful and useable R
            packages.

articles.title: Scholarship
articles.contents:
Contents
Publications
R packages

I am an applied statistician and data scientist whose scholarly activities include incorporating realistic computation and visualization into the classroom, developing better visualizations to explore complex models, and R package development.
Publications
Loy, A. (2021). Bringing Visual Inference to the Classroom. Journal of Statistics and Data Science Education 29(2).
Maurer, K., Osthus, D., and Loy, A. (2019). A Tale of Four Cities: Exploring the Soul of State College, Detroit, Milledgeville, and Biloxi. Computational Statistics 34(4).
Loy, A., Kuiper, S., and Chihara, L. (2019). Supporting Data Science in the Statistics Curriculum. Journal of Statistics Education 27(1).
Almeida, A., Loy, A., and Hofmann, H. (2018). ggplot2 Compatible Quantile-Quantile Plots in R. The R Journal 10(2).
Loy, A., Hofmann, H., and Cook, D. (2017). Model Choice and Diagnostics for Linear Mixed-Effects Models Using Statistics on Street Corners. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics 26(3), 478– 492.
Loy, A., Follett, L., and Hofmann, H. (2016). Variations of Q-Q Plots—The Power of our Eyes! The American Statistician 70(2), 202–214.
Loy, A. and Hofmann, H. (2015). Are You Normal? The Problem of Confounded Residual Structures in Hierarchical Linear Models. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics 24(4), 1191–1209.

Arbuckle, J. G., Jr., Prokopy, L. S., Haigh, T., Hobbs, J., Knoot, T., Knutson, C., Loy, A., Mase, A. S., McGuire, J., Wright Morton, L., Tyndall, J., and Widhalm, M. (2013). Climate Change Beliefs, Concerns, and Attitudes toward Adaptation and Mitigation among Farmers in the Midwestern United States. Climatic Change 117(4), 943–950.
Loy, A. and Hofmann, H. (2013). Diagnostic Tools for Hierarchical Linear Models. Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Computational Statistics 5(1), 48–61.
Hofmann, H., Cook, D., Kielion, C., Schloerke, B., Hobbs, J., Loy, A., Mosley, L., Rockoff, D., Huang, Y., Wrolstad, D., and Yin, T. (2011). Delayed, Canceled, On Time, Boarding . . . Flying in the USA. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics 20(2), 287–290.

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
I teach statistics and data science courses at all levels at Carleton, and I strive to equip my students with the skills to learn from data so that they can make informed decisions in the presence of uncertainty.
2022-2023 academic year
Fall
Stat 230: Applied regression analysis
Stat 340: Bayesian statistics
Winter
Stat 220: Introduction to data science
Spring
Stat 120: Introduction to statistics
